name: DONEGAL postcards
description: CLICK FOR VIDEO In the furthest north-west corner of Ireland sits Donegal, a county defined by its terrain and the harsh winds of the Atlantic Sea. Days in Donegal are spent rambling in the hills, walking along beaches and exploring the rock pools and fishing spots. Nights are spent indoors by a peat fire, in a local pub or at home, in an area famed for the freshness of its seafood. And all the while, the wild Atlantic bashes relentlessly onto its rugged coastline. These photographs were taken by Stephen Edwards, a Donegal native; and Steve Messer, a regular visitor to the county. The postcards display the beauty of the incredible beauty of both the coastline and the landscape, and properly evoke that 'Wish you were here' glow. 4.13" x 5.82" Colour 350gsm gloss lam 4 pcs.

name: EVERYTHING SUCKS zine
description: CLICK FOR VIDEO Like a walk from the suburbs to the centre of the city, Stephanie Mill's debut photo-zine grows and changes on each stage of the journey. On the outskirts life is quiet, free time spent hanging with buds, drinking brews and DIY tattoos. But as the youths grab their backpacks and head inland, the scene soon changes: walls dripping with fresh graffiti, skate spots galore and a gutsy nightlife. The action ascends, evenings explode and we're met with a crescendo between moments and breaths. The final conclusion: everything sucks. Or does it? Stephanie Mill is a 21-year-old photographer from the suburbs of Toronto. Moving to the centre of town to pursue an BFA in Photography at OCAD, she has been widely published for her open and honest style. Everything Sucks is her first solo publication. A5 Colour Saddle-stitched 48 pp. First edition of thirty copies

name: LONDON zine
description: CLICK FOR VIDEO London is the capital city of England and the United Kingdom. It attracts 14 million international visitors a year – as many people as it is home to – and is one of the most renowned cities in the world. London offers up some of its highlights from off the tourist trail, and pockets of the place without a red bus in sight; shades of the city removed from the souvenir-selling serfdom it thrives off. A5 Colour Saddle-stitched 20 pp. First edition of thirty copies

name: HARSH BROWNS zine
description: CLICK FOR VIDEO A document of one boy’s last week of unemployment. Filled with uncertainty and expectation, it charts the self-made rites of passage into adulthood and remembers everything that will be left behind. A5 Black and white Saddle-stitched 56 pp. First edition of thirty copies
